message: Considering the relevance of the OEIS (Online Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences), I'm surprised to see only few members here. I suppose that will change.
​'s more frequent than weekly posts alone would be a good reason! Thanks for that, Peter!
Refurio: The main OEIS-related traffic is on the SeqFan-mailing list:

One of the advantages of OEIS Google group over the mailing list is the easy way of linking images. I often do this when I want to tell about any intriguing (or just beautiful) graph (scatter plot) I have found.
I heard only good things about SeqFan, that's a very nice suggestion,
Regrettably I'm limiting myself to g+ - for now. But I'll make sure to follow your suggestion once I'm done inventoring the fun stuff (maths) here on g+.
Short historical intros into various bits of mathematics. What the title says. I've counted 12 posts in the last 4 wèeks,
That's a cool habit you have there,
It's safe to post about higher maths in this community, it's what people do here. A nice place with quite some 6000 listeners and various authors. Check it out!
It's low traffic, but with posts every few months clearly alive, and tidily on topic. I'm looking forward to see the occasional gem in my stream having clicked "join" should yield.
Another set of posts on graph theory.
​​ has been active every few weeks, resharing news and nice examples from the field. That's cool! But it makes me curious what you, Sridhar, were thinking when posting these...
​​'s math collection is full of well written posts, many animations, and while much of it is aimed at a popular audience, that includes the latest breakthroughs, and also many advanced topics!
For most weeks I've counted up to a handful posts, many of which easily got 100 likes.
​​ seems put up some new posts every few weeks. You can find some nice proofs here, have a look!
Keep up the good work, this is cool stuff! Subscribed.﻿

is a massive multiplayer game where it's useful to know your maths! This active community is about that maths, giving statistical insights into latest in-game developments, strategic analysis employing geometry, and pointers to the latest news and talks!
How serious could they be about it? Go and have a look!
Do you use commercial mathematics packages like Mathematica, MATLAB, or maybe even Maple? Or perhaps you prefer to light up their opensource siblings, like Maxima, Octave, or Pari/gp?
​​'s SAGE, you can have all of the latter in one place together with a whole lot of other, often more specialized systems, like GAP, SymPy, Singular, or even R!
The community below has all you need: Announcements, support and discussion, and even room for developers. Be a sage, too! Click and see:
Thanks -- if anybody has any questions, here I am. AMA.
Yeah, that's the spirit I forgot to mention. Cool! Thank
for your work! And thanks for resharing.﻿
As you probably know, LaTeX is
standard to typeset (or just write up) mathematical publications. Below, you find an active g+ community with announcement posts, discussion and support, and an occasional advocacy statement.
Though not about maths itself, many of the posts you can find here are by and for mathematicians. A nifty resource, join now!
Another fan community! It's not exactly alive, but it's about a mathematician unlike any other. There should be
to tell about Paul Erdös, I'm tempted to try a search and paste my finds into that group. Someone with me?

Here's another fan community, but Leonard Susskind is very much alive. That explains the larger count of members and perhaps the relatively recent posts (as in ripe cheese). But it doesn't look encouraging. Do you know of other math celebrity fan communities? Please tell...

Everybody loves Richard Feynman, of course there's a fan community! Since Feynman is no more, news are rare, and this community hasn't seen a fresh post for a long time now. I suspect that an archival community makes sense, but I don't think that's what we see here. Too bad.
Guys, he's gone! No news anymore...
Somehow I misread the figures. The latest post here is 5 weeks younger than the latest in Susskinds fan community!
Here's what I think must be the most popular
maths collection. Some 57.000 people want to see whatever
​​​ posts there. Hey folks, John did write about these things, and I'd bet a horse he isn't done yet. You can't see 4d in the normal way, so no surprise here. Go search for "John Baez
That's a nice general maths collection you have there,
​! Simon reshares his finds up to a few times a week. Have a look!
, but not enough posts to fill them. Here's a community that even has a category in its name. But usually that's not a problem, and it's sort of nice to get suggestions for posts that way.
However, there are multiple people posting on topic here, which means you'll find people here who
​​ is doing a splendid job curating the gaps. He has a nice taste covering entry level stuff, news and events, and sometimes other gems. Thanks for that!
What else could one wish for? Come on and join in!

​ is an algebraic geometer whose reading habits range deep into neighbouring topics. Many classics, occasionally nice entry level stuff, and much of it for free! A nice collection, go and rummage a bit for yourself, I'm sure you won't be disappointed.

​​ is studying works by Grothendieck and Bourbaki, and I've found one post having a 'beginner' word in it. Which is quite fitting, because the mentioned authors (and author collectives) are known to be a challenging longtime occupation for their readers.
If knew some french already - that might help, but do take a look, most of the links point to freely accessible stuff. Nice work Benjamin, I can't wait for more!
Here is what seems to be
​'s community to promote her books. It's an

community, and I like the impression that gives me; that I'm welcome to discuss the books and maybe related topics here. The tagline doesn't even limit the topic, and maybe this community has the potential to become much more than what it is now.
If that's the idea, you've got my best wishes! Well done in any case!
​ posts about diff. equations, geometry, and more. Notice the tools he works with!

Looking at the size of this community, I think I have to revise my estimate for how many people are working in set theory. These people are serious about math. The posters are various, but of late the frequency seems to be half a post per month. I'll keep an eye on that one!
That's really a nice topic you have there! Too bad there's only been one burst of posts about a year ago. That's a pity because the subject is very much a living one. But I do like the picture.
Update: Oh no, there were two (smaller) bursts. I have to remember to look at the first unpinned post.
Another detail, right now, there are more categories than posts. It's "noncommutative" and not "non commutative", and the category titles get that right. Extra score!
Those are some nice 13 finds you shared 13 weeks ago. Any chance you get back to look for more,
​'s latest fancy: Pictures of graphs with intriguing symmetry! It's a fresh one, posts range back 7 only weeks, but it's got some fascinating views already. Looking forward to see more of these!
With a handful of posts a week by various authors this community is very much alive. It's about stuff I would find in my streams, with some real math gems. Subscribed.
This one is a real gem! On most days, you'll find
​​​​​​ jamming the jazz, showing off and discussing their latest formulas and finds.

! While communities with a few dominant posters often make me suspicious, it's not like that with them! When I recently played some of my own tunes at this nice place, I found myself part of a larger song.
I'm here to stay. What about you?

Thank you for the very kind comments. I guess the main goal of mine is to learn from others. Also, if possible, try to help them as well. The group that Roger created is really neat. He knows a heck of a lot about fractal geometry and I love learning from his work.
Also, try to check out Paul Bourke's excellent site, if you have not already:

Thanks for your response! I think I've gained a magnitude or two of knowledge since I last tried to better understand the M-set, and 'd be more open for dynamical theory in general. Learning together is
Yeah, Paul's is a very nice site. I should have another look :)﻿
​​ is math professor at the university of Boulder Colorado. He is widely known on g+ for his well written posts popularizing concepts from higher maths.
You can find all of them in this mathematics collection!
In addition to the cool explanations aimed at the layman, references, and never missing a catchy image, his posts often spur long discussions involving experts and everybody else... You?
I got the idea for my
blog from following Richard Green. His collection is top-notch.
Yeah, his math posts are fun!
​ also had a hand in getting me going. I felt I had to give something back, resharing wasn't enough anymore...
Less is more? Nonesense. More is more! The infinite is more than the finite. And there are many more infinities than finite'ies... you get the idea.
​, a renowed researcher in mathematical logic, has recently begun to collect posts about his work below the fold.
Logic is infamous for being a notoriously difficult topic, but his posts easily convey the shocking moments that come with progress in the field.
Nice one, I'm looking forward to see more.

Here my first reshare of a collection post by someone else! "Mathematics & Geometry " is as fresh as fresh can be and has acquired 31 members only just now. It is currently mostly curated by their owners,
​, you'll find nice little enjoyable facts there.
Don't forget to click through to the original post, it has nice comments you wouldn't want to miss!

link.title: Mathematics & Geometry
link.description: For All Lovers Of The Mathematics

message: In case you like large numbers, fast growing functions, ordinal notations, approaching higher infinities, or just to hang out with other cardinal guests at Hilbert's hotel, then this collection is for you!
​​ recently gathered his cool posts on this topic very dear to me. Go and spend an afternoon or two catching up about the long run to and beyond the infinite.
​​ is interested in applications and mathatical models. Below the fold you'll find a stream of links to nice news posts, about 7 per month. Thanks Pietro!
​ for the invitation! I will enjoy.
​! Thanks for reminding me that mathematics has an applied side %-)
are the conformal mappings from a 2-sphere to itself. Riemann taught us that the complex numbers are best seen as coordinates on a sphere. So we're looking at functions of the form C -> C.
if it preserves angles almost everywhere. We could alternatively require it to take circles to circles and preserve orientation.
There are even more ways to get at this, and the 2-dimensional complex case happens to be
exceptionally rich special case as far as conformal mappings go.
The full set of all these functions is a group that goes by the fancy name
2 dimensional projective special linear group over C
, and it can be represented as the set of 2x2 matrices with complex entries and determinant 1.
if it is a subgroup of
You can also get a Kleinian group by taking a bunch of simple conformal distortions of the plane, and then combine them, applying one after another until the group is complete.
As in this case the conformal mappings coincide with the analytical functions, we get their richness as well, and some authors generalize Kleinian groups, adding limit pictures to the whole.

Pictures like Julia sets! We get these by transforming an initial circle in all possible ways, picking either of the two branches of the inverse of the quadratic function given by the seed constant and the Mandelbrot map.

They're all Kleinian groups! You see, the maps don't have to be surjective, or injective to be conformal. Indeed, many Kleinian groups like to live on manifolds. Impossible lattices, and all sorts of strange creatures are hiding here.
I don't think I could ever get bored looking at these,

Oh wow, I must have dozed away while typing, it got a bit longer than expected. I hope I didn't just scare away someone (you?), about to share a math collection with just a few simple words. Please don't leave, your find will be appreciated!
Originally shared by Abdelaziz Nait Merzouk

features cool original writeups like the post below. And in between, people gather in the comment sections of well picked news shares.
That's a nice drive you have there, Paul, keep up the good work!

Time to write some mathematics...I'm thinking about ridiculously big numbers and where they arise. Surely thinking about ridiculously big numbers is one of the things mathematicians are "meant" to do, right?

of the mathematician Gauss assets that for a large number x, the spacing between primes close to x is approximately log x, and this approximation becomes more and more accurate the larger the number x is.
One can ask whether the average distance between prime numbers below x is greater than log x or less than log x.
Computations suggest that this average distance may always be less than log x; for example, a 2008 computation verifies this is so for all numbers less than 10^14, that is 1 with 14 zeros after it.

However, surprisingly, this is not always the case. The number theorist Littlewood proved in 1914 that there are large numbers for which the average distance is greater than log x. The question is then how one might find such numbers, bearing in mind how large they are.
Such an exploration is beyond the scope of this post. An estimate dating from 1933 due to Skewes gives a number x=10^(10^(10^43)) where such is the case. This number is

large. 10^43 is 1 with 43 zeroes after it. 10^(10^43) is 1 with 10^43 zeroes after it. So 10^(10^(10^43)) is 1 with 10^(10^43) zeroes after it. The number is simply too large to picture. It exceeds considerably the number of elementary particles in the entire universe.

Fortunately, more recent estimates have found a small number x that will work. The smallest result that I know of (Bays-Hudson, 2000) gives an estimate of x=10^312, that is 1 with 312 zeroes after it. This is still an absolutely enormous number, but seems rather modest compared to Skewes' number.

for stuff to appear in his very interesting "GRAPH THEORY" collection:
I like your short intros and cool finds Aaron! Folks, have a look and click follow!

In mathematics, spectral graph theory is the study of properties of a graph in relationship to the characteristic polynomial, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors of matrices associated to the graph, such as its adjacency matrix or Laplacian matrix.
An undirected graph has a symmetric adjacency matrix and therefore has real eigenvalues (the multiset of which is called the graph's spectrum) and a complete set of orthonormal eigenvectors.
While the adjacency matrix depends on the vertex labeling, its spectrum is a graph invariant.
Spectral graph theory is also concerned with graph parameters that are defined via multiplicities of eigenvalues of matrices associated to the graph, such as the Colin de Verdière number.

. It's well curated with pictures, explanations and links. Even the occasional link-dropping posts are quite informative. Quality stuff you shouldn't miss!
The writhing number measures the global geometry of a
In knot theory, there are several competing notions of the quantity writhe, or Wr

. In one sense, it is purely a property of an oriented link diagram and assumes integer values. In another sense, it is a quantity that describes the amount of "coiling" of a mathematical knot (or any closed, simple curve) in three-dimensional space and assumes real numbers as values. In both cases, writhe is a geometric quantity, meaning that while deforming a curve (or diagram) in such a way that does not change its topology, one may still change its writhe
Normal holonomy and writhing number of polygonal knots
Computing the Writhing Number of a Polygonal Knot

Here we describe the properties of ideal forms of composite knots — knots obtained by the sequential tying of two or more independent knots (called factor knots) on the same string. We find that the writhe (related to the handedness of crossing points) of composite knots is the sum of that of the ideal forms of the factor knots. By comparing ideal composite knots with simulated configurations of knotted, thermally fluctuating DNA, we conclude that the additivity of writhe applies also to randomly distorted configurations of composite knots and their corresponding factor knots. We show that composite knots with several factor knots may possess distinct structural isomers that can be interconverted only by loosening the knot.
The writhing number measures the global geometry of a

. In one sense, it is purely a property of an oriented link diagram and assumes integer values. In another sense, it is a quantity that describes the amount of "coiling" of a mathematical knot (or any closed, simple curve) in three-dimensional space and assumes real numbers as values. In both cases, writhe is a geometric quantity, meaning that while deforming a curve (or diagram) in such a way that does not change its topology, one may still change its writhe
Normal holonomy and writhing number of polygonal knots
Computing the Writhing Number of a Polygonal Knot

Here we describe the properties of ideal forms of composite knots — knots obtained by the sequential tying of two or more independent knots (called factor knots) on the same string. We find that the writhe (related to the handedness of crossing points) of composite knots is the sum of that of the ideal forms of the factor knots. By comparing ideal composite knots with simulated configurations of knotted, thermally fluctuating DNA, we conclude that the additivity of writhe applies also to randomly distorted configurations of composite knots and their corresponding factor knots. We show that composite knots with several factor knots may possess distinct structural isomers that can be interconverted only by loosening the knot.

​'s cool communities. This time it's about tilings and tesselations. The latest post is from today, the last gap was about 5 weeks long. It's reasonably active for a young community with just about 130 mebers by now.

Now that I've had some chance to look connect with the larger fractal community I noticed that Roger is often described as legendary. I'm not surprised. He's all in into chaos, dynamical and fractal stuff, a true nerd. Go and have a look at his 'interests' communities on his profile, many of which were started by him!
Actually the "fathers" to my communities on Google+ are
yahoo groups: active and true types. ( subscribe to true tile at true_tile-subscribe@yahoogroups.com)

I still post there more often than Google+ which is about to force a very hard to post in new format on our communities. Google+ communities archives don't have file databases or very good image databases. The only real advantage to google+ is popularity which is probably over-rated in importance, LOL.

message: ​​​ makes animations like this cool snub dodecahedron folding over to a mustbea-stellated whatisit-hedron one in processing, and curates teasers to his work in this wonderful collection:
They all have a mathematical background and many show classical ideas in fresh colors. Go now and enjoy! Cool stuff, Sean!
The prickly Inversion of a Snub Dodecahedron

It tumbled away and awkwardly came to an unseemly rest. A naked pile of shards unintentionally revealed.  All the untidy truths had punctured through the affected membrane of calm, revealed in sharp edges and wicked points. This is it, do you see?
This is an animation from 2015. Polyhedrons occupied most of my attention once I got my legs with 3D Processing techniques. I'll revisit them in Blender at some point I imagine.

There is a lot more happening with and around the Coq proof assistant than
​​​​​​' community currently reflects. Let's take it as a good sign! More room for starters! Share your first experiences there and I hereby promise to try and help you over a few hurdles!
You may have seen me post a link to
That was just before I found this community. I wouldn't be surprised if Arnaud has more to tell, so keep looking out, even if I grew unhappy making a fuss about it. Cheers!
As usual you'll find a representative post below the fold, click through the blue category link to find the community.
with mathy stuff? You're very welcome to share it here! Or reshare a post from it, if you also take care to link your g+ collection, so people can find more posts like it.
or other people's g+ collections, if related to math, they are all welcome here. We all want to know! Don't be shy, share!
In case you're looking for responses on a particular subject or result of yours, please consider posting to one of the many communities listed below, instead.

I'd like to use the opportunity to thank everyone who posted here, engaged with a post, or reads here, in short: You. And also to all the nice people who collect or talk about math stuff, and especially those who come up with cool posts we all like reading so much: Thank you!﻿
​​! May the maths be with you and your blog never end!
I've recently started a new blog dedicated to all things math-related. The blog is called just that,
. It will be a Google+ collection that I will update regularly, in hopes of sparring good discussion of mathematical concepts. There will also be some jokes & humor added. Hope to see you there.
